subject: Re: [junit] Question on assertEquals()
msgSnippet: I guess that s because JUnit doesn t have assertion methods taking Set/Collection/Object[] as parameters. You have to perform an assertion for both Set s
messageBody:
I guess that's because JUnit doesn't have assertion methods taking
Set/Collection/Object[] as parameters. You have to perform an assertion for
both Set's sizes, sort them, make a loop and compare each element. Something
like this...

--
Tiago Fernandez
http://www.tiago182.spyw.com

On 4/24/06, marcoschicote <marcoschicote@...> wrote:
>
> I've written an app using Java 1.4 and I was trying to test it using
> JUnit 1.3.8. The app uses Hibernate 3 for DB connection.
> I'm running a test with JUnit which does the following: creates an
> object (Curso A), saves it to the DB using hibernate, retrieves the
> object (again using Hibernate) (Curso B) and compares boths objects to
> see if they are equal.
>
> I can see in the DB that the object was saved correctly.
>
> When I retrive the object, I compare, using setters and getters, Curso
> B vs Curso A. All comparisons are done using assertEquals. Everything
> works fine, except for one attribute. Object like Curso B and Curso A
> have a Set in their private section. When I compare the Set I get the
> following error:
>
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
> expected:<[corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.entidad.Programacion@4eeaaf,
> corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.entidad.Programacion@fa39d7,
> corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.entidad.Programacion@111bfbc]> but
> was:<[corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.entidad.Programacion@7244ca,
> corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.entidad.Programacion@61373f,
> corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.entidad.Programacion@11410e5]>
> at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
> at junit.framework.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:282)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:64)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:71)
> at
> corp.cencosud.easy.cursos.test.CencosudEasyCursosTest.testSaveGetCurso(
> CencosudEasyCursosTest.java:257)
> at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
> at
> sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java
> :39)
> at
> sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(
> DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
> at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.runTest(TestCase.java:154)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:127)
> at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)
> at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124)
> at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109)
> at junit.framework.TestCase.run(TestCase.java:118)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest(TestSuite.java:208)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:203)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest(TestSuite.java:208)
> at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:203)
> at
> org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(
> RemoteTestRunner.java:421)
> at
> org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(
> RemoteTestRunner.java:305)
> at
> org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(
> RemoteTestRunner.java:186)
>
> I've implemented equals() for the objects that are contained in the
> set, but for some reason, JUnit never calls this function.
>
> Can anyone help me?
>
> Thanks a lot. If you need some more info, just ask!
>
